description.narrative: Supporting anti-corruption stakeholders in Lebanon to maintain the momentum for national dialogue and capacity development in preparation for the formal adoption and implementation of the country’s first-ever national anti-corruption strategy.

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: Number of new specialized anti-corruption bills amended and/or passed. Scope of compliance with access to information law by ministries and municipalities Number of gender-specific policy recommendations formulated and disseminated to enhance the content and implementation of anti-corruption legislation Number of participatory processes (with representation from women’s organizations) to assess corruption risks in the pilot sectors

comment.narrative: First national anti-corruption strategy developed and formally presented it in April 2018. Two ministerial committees were established in 2011. Access to Information Law passed in 2017. Number of Anti - Corruption Laws not passed yet.

1- Develop and implement a campaign and ads strategy for Anti-corruption videos, as part of a knowledge sharing and awareness raising on anti-corruption in Lebanon. 2- Develop an interactive chat bot on Facebook to raise awareness in an innovative way and targeted for specific audience. 3- Increase knowledge of women organizations on anti-corruption in Lebanon. 4- Provide technical support in drafting legislation to Parliamentarians. 5- Provide technical support to OMSAR in the implementation of the Access to Information Law, through providing advice on the development of a guide for Information Officers on the law. 6- Testing and Mapping the compliance of municipalities and federations to the Access to Information Law.

1- The user friendly chatbot previously created as an innovative tool to raise awareness among the younger population on anti-corruption topics was updated in the context of the latest updates in terms of passing the NACS and the law on the National Anti-Corruption Institution. It is now ready to be launched. 2- In the context of launching the anti-corruption related videos, the subpages on the UNDP’s website were created “offline” and content and images/visuals integrated, ready for the launching of the videos 3- Supported the launch of the “Guide for International Cooperation with the Lebanese Republic to Recover Assets originating from Corrupt Acts” in partnership with the Ministry of Justice on May 18, 2020. A joint press release was published for this occasion

- At least 1 high level parliamentary seminar on the UNCAC and anti-corruption legislations with Lebanese Parliamentarians against Corruption. - At least 4 consultative meetings with civil society representatives including women’s organizations to support anti-legislative agenda in Lebanon, including law on Access to Information. - Train Information Officers in public administrations on the implementation of the Access to Information Law - Support civil society in monitoring and publicly reporting on the progress of the implementation of the access to information law. - Provide technical assistance to stakeholders to finalize pending bills and submit them for adoption. - Provide technical assistance to the finalization of the National Anti-Corruption Strategy and submit it for adoption. - Implement corruption risk management in three sectors. - Gender Mainstreaming in Fighting Corruption.

• Supported the Lebanese Parliamentarians Against Corruption (LebPAC) in reaching consensus on the way forward after the above stated law was returned back to Parliament by the President of the Republic in July 2019. • Provided technical support to the established sub-committee on drafting the National Action Plan for Implementing the Access to Information Law. • Provided advisory support on the implementation decree of the Access to Information law. • Increased compliance with the Access to Information law by public administrations, through mapping the current status of Information Officers (IOs) and increasing their capacities on the law, in coordination with the Office of the State Minister for Administrative Reform (OMSAR). • Engaged civil society organizations in the finalization of the national action plan on the implementation of the Access to Information law. • Assisted in the creation of a bridge between civil society organizations and the government through supporting “Gherbal Initiative” in the framework of its work on ensuring compliance of public administrations to the Access to Information law. • Increased compliance of a number of municipalities and federations to the Access to Information Law through engaging with “Gherbal Initiative” to conduct a mapping and testing of their compliance with the law as well as increasing awareness and developing portals in the framework of the implementation of the law. • Created a platform for civil society organizations working on anti-corruption to stay informed on the national efforts in this regard. • Participated in the process of and complemented the revision and update of the National Anti-Corruption Strategy. • Explored gender dimensions in corruption and identified entry points on gender mainstreaming in anti-corruption. • Explored the impact of corruption on women compared to men in three sectors, health, labor and customs to inform related policy discussions and corruption risk management initiatives in Lebanon. • Supported the representation of 4 women member of parliament in the LebPAC coalition. • Increased awareness on corruption risk management and demand from public institutions to implement the methodology (two official approvals in two sectors: labor and customs and request received from Ministry of Environment). • Increased awareness of civil society organizations on corruption risk assessment methodology through conducting a three-day training for more than 20 representatives of CSOs. • Updated and reviewed the corruption risk methodology and integrated a gender lens into it.
